key_points: Tom Brady led the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to a 31-9 victory over the Kansas City Chiefs in Super Bowl LV.
Brady's performance in the game emphasized his dominance over Patrick Mahomes, contributing to the win.
Brady, at 43, threw three touchdown passes in the first half, completing 21-of-29 passes overall.
Mahomes had the worst game of his career, completing 26-of-49 passes for 270 yards with two interceptions and no touchdowns.
This Super Bowl marked the lowest point output for a Mahomes-led offense and his first game without a touchdown.
Mahomes faced significant pressure, being rushed on 29 drop-backs, while Brady faced minimal sack pressure.
The difference in play highlighted Brady's experience and Mahomes' need for adjustment to in-game situations.
Brady's strategy focused on efficiency and taking advantage of pre-snap reads rather than relying on skill alone.
This game served as a humbling moment for Mahomes, underscoring lessons in strategy and composure.
Despite criticism, Brady's approach and Super Bowl LV win cement his status as one of the greatest NFL quarterbacks.
